Award.AbstractNarration:
Homeless Service Systems and the Homeless
Christopher Herring

Homeless management in the US city relies on the street, shelter, and state supported housing programs. Social scientists do not have a clear understanding of how these institutions relate to one another within an internal economy of homeless management and how these relationships shape the survival of the houseless. Further, every city in the United has an insufficient supply of shelter beds and homeless housing units. There is, then, an important empirical puzzle as to how, why, and when, in this context of housing scarcity, certain individuals and groups end up in one institution rather than another. Rather than just view homelessness as an outcome of poverty, this dissertation seeks to explain the role institutions of homeless management play in sorting and stratifying the poor and possibly deepening the poverty of the precariously housed through policy toward the homeless. This dissertation research will integrate several fields of study in sociology, social welfare and public health and help understand the ways in which policy affects marginalized groups.

To answer the empirical puzzle of who gets what and when within a homeless services system, the dissertation will provide a comparative study of the streets, shelters, and permanent supportive housing programs in the city of San Francisco; a city considered a national model for its multi-service shelters and "housing first" approach. The study will adjudicate among three common explanations of institutional entry, restriction, and preference: (a) institutional factors (b) discretionary factors and (c) individual factors that affect their entry, exit, restriction, and circulation between street, shelter, and homeless housing. The dissertation will also assess how residing within one institution or another affects health, work, welfare, criminalization, and social ties. These processes will be studied through a "multi-sided ethnography," working alongside social workers on the streets, shelters, and permanent supportive housing on the one hand, and navigating alongside homeless people through these same spaces. This research contributes to the sociology of the homeless, social welfare, sociology of poverty and has strong broader impacts in its potential contribution to homeless and housing policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although social scientists have long studied the signature institutions of homeless management in the US city; namely the street, shelter, and state supported housing programs, we lack a clear understanding of how these institutions relate to one another within an internal economy of homeless management and how their co-dependent inclusions and exclusions shape the survival of the houseless. While every city in the United States regulates homelessness through these three institutions, nearly all have an insufficient supply of shelter beds and homeless housing units. This raises an important empirical puzzle as to how, why, and when, in this context of scarcity, certain individuals and groups end up in one institution rather than another. Rather than taking homelessness as simply the outcome of poverty, this dissertation seeks to explain the role institutions of homeless management play in stratifying, sorting, and separating the poor and the diverse ways these spaces of seclusion mitigate, deepen, or fossilize the poverty of the precariously housed through their inevitable inclusions and exclusions.

 

Drawing on ethnographic observations from residing with those on the streets, shelters, supportive housing units and working alongside the social workers, police officers, politicians, and organizers addressing homelessness in San Francisco, the study made a series of discoveries. Prioritization for both criminalization by policing and social services through social workers on the streets are first and foremost driven by "consumer complaints" by housed residents, merchants, business improvement districts, and political actors rather than criminal behavior or medical, mental health, or general need or vulnerability. This challenges both portrayals in the current scholarship of policing as forms of top-down zero-tolerance campaigns of aggressive patrol and coercive benevolence that ignore the role of caller-demand and the grassroots sources of such policing efforts, as well as the portrayals of the medicalization of poverty that ignore the political and economic uses of "medicalized responses."

 

Within the shelter system and supportive housing the research uncovered various mechanisms through which homeless individuals are not only assisted, but also exploited, deprived, and further impoverished through their institutionalization. Rather than understanding these institutions as forms of welfare assistance, the dissertation argues that they should also be understood as forms of punitive containment highlighting the high rate of turnover across the shelter and housing units, frequency and practices of eviction and denial of services, and how these particularly discriminate against those suffering from drug addiction, mental health problems, or criminal backgrounds. Rather than humanitarian care, workfare discipline, criminalization, harm reduction, or medicalization, the overriding administrative logics of both institutions were clearly the neutralization of homelessness, budgetary cost-containment, and political calculation.

 

Collectively the findings elaborate how "service resistance" is produced by the local state through a fragmented and contested bureaucratic field - as a host of agencies including the police, public health, sanitation, probations, sheriff, and human services departments, along with courts, medics, and district politicians each aim to shift the cost and labor burdens of managing homelessness within their various jurisdictions. The outcome, as illustrated through this dissertation’s multi-sided ethnographies, being the perpetuation of homelessness and reproduction of poverty that widens inequalities along lines of race, disability, age, and sexuality. 

 

Over the course of the research I collaborated with both community organizers and policymakers. The research supported significant criminal justice reforms around the criminalization of homelessness in San Francisco including the admonishments of tens of thousands of bench warrants issued to homeless people who received quality of life citations and could not pay, the issuance of a Budget Analysts Office report on the cost of criminalizing homelessness in the city of San Francisco, and the ending of the practice of sending unpaid citations for anti-homeless laws to collection agencies and revoking driver’s license. I'm now currently working with the city's shelter monitoring committee and Department of homelessness in helping shape reforms within the shelters and supportive housing programs.
